nodes.body:
The demonstratives འདི་ (proximal), དེ་ (medial), and ཕ་གི་ (distal) denote three degrees of removal: nearby, distant, and far-off, corresponding to the English expressions “here,” “there,” and “over there.”

The demonstratives འདི་, དེ་, and ཕ་གི་ function as pronouns and adjectives. When used as adjectives, demonstratives always come after the noun (or after the noun phrase), and carry a case or plural marker as appropriate:

  • འདི་ག་རེ་རེད། “What is this?” (“This is what?”)
  • ཤོག་གུ་འདི་ག་རེ་རེད། “What is this paper?”
  • ཤོག་གུ་འདི་ཚོ་ག་རེ་རེད། “What are these papers?”

The demonstratives འདི་ and དེ་ are employed not only to draw attention to something, to point out something, or to show something (deictic function), but also to refer to elements previously mentioned (anaphoric function) in a text or conversation. The expression ཕ་གི་, however, is used only to indicate spatial distance.

The demonstrative འདི་ is linked to the present moment; དེ་, on the other hand, is associated with the past or the future, and with the notions of “the beyond” and the invisible.

  • ངས་དེ་ཞུས་པ་ཡིན། “I said that.”
  • ངས་འདི་ཞུ་གི་ཡིན། “I’ll say this.”
  • ལོ་འདི་ “This year” (present)
  • ལོ་དེ་ “That year” (past or future)
  • དེབ་འདི་ “This book”
  • དེབ་དེ་ “That book”
  • དེབ་ཕ་གི་ “That book over there”

The demonstratives འདི་, དེ་, and ཕ་གི་ are used to form the adverbs འདིར་, དེར་, and ཕ་གིར་ “here,” “there,” and “over there.” In the spoken language they have undergone a small variation in their pronunciation: འདིའི་ (འདིར་), ཕ་གའི་ (ཕ་གིར་).
